{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3375723,"name":"Amaan","username":"AmaanCADs","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/amaancads/{size}/257471_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T03:18:48.816Z","cooked":"

Hello! So here‚Äôs my end-of-April dilemma: I was scrolling on Instagram a while back when I came across this post: JBV on Instagram: "Gears that mesh on perpendicular axes ü§Ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Normal spur gears need to have parallel axes in order to properly mesh. Sometimes, situation arise where you need the gears to mesh on perpendicular axes. This can be achieved by taking a regular spur gear and twisting it 90 degrees. I designed this quick test print to prove this concept, and it resulted in a really cool demonstration of the principle that also makes for a fun fidget toy. The download files are available for free on JBVCreative.com if you want to try printing it yourself! ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ #mechanical #mechanicalengineering #mechanism #gear #gearporn #3dprinting #engineering"

The first thing that came to my mind was ‚Äúwhy haven‚Äôt I seen this in FRC gearboxes?‚Äù I am well aware that bevel gearboxes (like that of a 90-degree MAXPLANETARY) do indeed exist and are commonly used in FRC, and after talking a bit with my CAD mentor, learned that worm gears also are (or should I say, were) somewhat used within drivetrains a handful of years ago. But upon some general research (including here on CD) I didn‚Äôt really find anything as for if hyperboloid gears (the ones within the video) have ever been tested within the FRC world. As such, I came to ask all of y‚Äôall the following: has this ever been tested within FRC? Is there really a practical custom application for this (vs that of a custom bevel gearbox)? Could this have the possibility of being able to take higher torque and/or loads compared to other gear solutions?

I‚Äôll also provide an interesting image that I found on a few different types of gears, among which hyperboloid gears are mentioned:

en-gear-types-overview1920√ó1080 202 KB

Lastly, I figured that I would also CAD a gearbox for y‚Äôall to see what I am envisioning from all of this: Onshape.

At the end of the day, I am not an expert on this subject matter, so all of this might just look really dumb lol. Thanks in advance!

I am pretty sure hypoid gears are different from hyperboloid gears; hypoid gears are essentially bevel gears with the two gear axes not intersecting each other.

AmaanCADs:

learned that worm gears also are (or should I say, were) somewhat used within drivetrains a handful of years ago.

I believe AM still sells this gearbox: RAW Box - AndyMark, Inc

That being said, that probably explains most of why you haven‚Äôt seen [insert power transmission concept] in FRC; what‚Äôs commonly used is mostly driven by what COTS components exist. Something existing as a COTS component has a lot of cost and mass manufacturability concerns that aren‚Äôt an issue for a one-off team project though, so don‚Äôt necessarily take that as an indication that it won‚Äôt work or provide some benefit.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T03:57:30.527Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":596,"readers_count":595,"score":179.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464777,"topic_slug":"hyperbolic-hyperboloid-screw-gears-in-frc","display_username":"Rahul Yarlagadda","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.andymark.com/products/raw-box","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"RAW Box - AndyMark, Inc","clicks":99}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7457 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/hyperbolic-hyperboloid-screw-gears-in-frc/464777/9","custom_user_title":"7457 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3375762,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T03:58:12.372Z","cooked":"

Might be off by a year, I remember it being a 2003 model but don‚Äôt remember it returning for 2004.

Not that my team really bothered with it, we went for the Bosch transmission and chain reductions generally.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T03:58:12.372Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":548,"readers_count":547,"score":119.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":464777,"topic_slug":"hyperbolic-hyperboloid-screw-gears-in-frc","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":1549,"username":"Richard_Wallace","name":"Richard Wallace","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/richard_wallace/{size}/110760_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/hyperbolic-hyperboloid-screw-gears-in-frc/464777/10","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3375787,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T04:05:42.983Z","cooked":"

These hung around the shop for all my years as a student (2011-2014) as a fidget toy next to the lead screws and igus energy chain.

I am thinking of a pair of hyperboloid gears about 1.5 inches OD, 3/4 inch facewidth, and a ~1/2 inch bore. Steel.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T04:07:08.457Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":505,"readers_count":504,"score":101.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464777,"topic_slug":"hyperbolic-hyperboloid-screw-gears-in-frc","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/hyperbolic-hyperboloid-screw-gears-in-frc/464777/11","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3375789,"name":"Amaan","username":"AmaanCADs","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/amaancads/{size}/257471_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T04:08:56.596Z","cooked":"

That‚Äôs a nice point. I am still though, ever so slightly disheartened at the fact that hyperbolic gears don‚Äôt seem to have been widely tested within FRC, especially since (my one day of research is concluding to the idea that) it appears like it could be a capable concept that at least in the non-COTS world could prove beneficial (it‚Äôs not like I‚Äôll even convince REV to make a COTS version of this either way lmao).

The general reason that I started this thread is because 1. I wonder a lot lol, and 2. my team has had problems with the 90-degree MAXPLANETARY gears chipping, etc. Here is our build blog from this year that outlines the problem: 2220 Blue Twilight | 2024 Build Thread - #2 by SeanCh7

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T04:16:17.704Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":497,"readers_count":496,"score":109.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464777,"topic_slug":"hyperbolic-hyperboloid-screw-gears-in-frc","display_username":"Amaan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/2220-blue-twilight-2024-build-thread/443797/2","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"2220 Blue Twilight | 2024 Build Thread","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12760,"username":"Knufire","name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63987,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CAD/Design Lead"},"post_url":"/t/hyperbolic-hyperboloid-screw-gears-in-frc/464777/12","custom_user_title":"CAD/Design Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3375792,"name":"Richard Wallace","username":"Richard_Wallace","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/richard_wallace/{size}/110760_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T04:16:20.978Z","cooked":"

Still looking for old data on the Kit gearbox I recall. IIRC it was used by 931 Perpetual Chaos at the St. Louis and Midwest Regionals in 2004. I think we used CIMs to power it. The custom omnis on the other end are powered by Bosch drill gearboxes.

image687√ó865 65.1 KB

If anyone is wondering why there aren‚Äôt any bumpers ‚Äì this was before those were a thing.

edit/ Found a current example. Still can‚Äôt find the KoP documents from 2004, but I do recall the gears in that kit looked a lot like the ones shown in the link.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T04:22:13.217Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":415,"readers_count":414,"score":278.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464777,"topic_slug":"hyperbolic-hyperboloid-screw-gears-in-frc","display_username":"Andrew Schreiber","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":13}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4297,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I'm Retired"},"post_url":"/t/hyperbolic-hyperboloid-screw-gears-in-frc/464777/14","custom_user_title":"I'm Retired","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":13},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":17,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3375844,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T11:16:33.726Z","cooked":"

Generally speaking with any type of non straight cut gears the manufacturing cost is much higher than a standard spur gear. (Unless you‚Äôre 3D printing) I don‚Äôt know about hyperbolics, but many non-straight cut gears have to be matched pairs and you cannot change the size of one gear without also changing the other gear. For those reasons straight spur gears are by far the most common with miter and worm gears having their niches, and anything else is almost always custom made for a specific project/product. Custom gears aren‚Äôt a problem for 3D printing, but if thats not going to work, cost or machining abilities may be prohibitive.

We‚Äôve used the type of gears demonstrated on the video once before. We 3D printed them. It was for a light load, low speed application that had a tricky spacing requirement.

You can design them in a CAD program by starting with the sketch of the face of a spur gear. Then you have to do an extrude/revolve that turns the sketch at 45 degree angle as it extrudes. (Sorry that‚Äôs not a great explanation‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs been a while since we did this!)

Another interesting fact I don‚Äôt think anybody‚Äôs mentioned in the string, a bevel gear is only 93 to 95 percent efficient.

A hypoid gear is closer to 90% efficient.

But a helical bevel is close to 99 percent. Maybe our swerve drive systems should have helical bevels to gain back some of that power?

Or horizontal motors and spur gears or belts. To not need to turn the power.

Chart stolen from internet.

image768√ó543 59 KB

I‚Äôm sure this is hard to accomplish from a mass production standpoint but if a swerve company made hypoid gearsets for their modules they could improve final drive efficiency enough to make a difference in pushing power and acceleration.

Just the other day I was looking into COTS gears that do this but typically hypoids are too large for this application. The gears would need to be custom made.

Helical bevel gears have teeth that spiral like this. I think it increases the efficiency and reduces backlash, but I‚Äôm not sure. They are harder to manufacture than normal bevel gears, which is why you don‚Äôt see them that often.
